comments.commentBody: It is understandable to choose suicide over death by degrees.
Thank goodness there are other people, similarly in the mood for straight talk, who will vote for Sanders.
You are so correct: most of us in middle America feel this way!  The liberal elites dismissing Trump in these pages hailing from the NE and west coast are gravely underestimating his appeal.

Trump could handily beat Hillary. People are in the mood for straight talk, even if it's outrageous. Hillary's careful parsing of every sentence isn't going to fare well against his bluster.

And unless Democrats drop the PC defense of Islam, they're sunk. It's not just a fear of violent Islamist extremists. It's a fear of a religion that makes women cover themselves in scarves. This very "conservative" form of Islam seems incompatible with American ideals of liberty and equality. And unless Democrats talk about this, they'll lose to Trump.

Part of me says I'll never vote for Trump. Part of me says, what the heck, I'm sick of all the mealy mouthed, bought-and-paid-for politicians, so why not stick it to them all and vote for him! I'm appalled at some of what he says. But I don't like anyone else either. I'm sensible, I'm moderate...if I feel this way, I think an awful lot of other people do too.

Reply to MyTwoCents - If Mr Trump does the standard shift to the middle that all wingers do come general election time, he'll disarm the alarmists and create a Reagan style coalition that can beat Clinton. Republicans are desperate to get into the White House. The power they'd wield with a stacked House is Trump's biggest selling point. He'll say it's not about him, it's about them, and they'll believe it. He's not about to destruct, he's about to coalesce.

This discovery demonstrates cheating and deception on a rare level. This is not just garden-variety bending of the rules, it is a diabolical obfuscation. It is damning and despicable and not just for VW. It is a blight on the character of industrial Germany itself. Where is the shame?

In the U.S. Navy (and I daresay in the navy of the Federal Republic of Germany) the captain of the ship has the responsibility for everything that happens in his command. And he has authority commensurate with his responsibility. While the fault may reside with a junior person, the captain is still responsible. This keeps every one on their toes. Not so at VW? Apparently.

I often heard smug comments such as, "I'd never buy a local car because they cannot compete with the low emissions standards of European cars". We must also look at the effect that this has had on the local car manufacturing industry in many countries around the world that have often struggled to survive because of the market impact of the misleading claims of VW.

Maybe VW has backhandedly driven local manufacturers toward greater diversification which will one day prove the downfall of the German manufacturer.

Having worked as a mid level engineering manager for my entire career, I find it laughable that VW still tries to maintain only a few rogue engineers pulled this scheme off.  Especially in a German corporate environment which has an incredible pecking order that we are not familiar with here in the states.  These people are going to keep singing the same song hoping to avoid prosecution.
So, really, it's our fault because we didn't want another tank to fill.

Decisions of this magnitude for a company are not made by engineers or low-level managers. A decision about whether to use AdBlue, NOX scrubbers or another method had to be made by a high-level executive. The decision would commit the company to spending many millions of dollars, and it would affect their strategic marketing plans for diesel.

I don't know if we'll ever find out the truth, but a LOT more than 9 people were responsible for this disastrous decision. By the way, the 9 were "suspended" not fired. Once this blows over VW can call them back.

"the deception reflected organizational shortcomings."

I guess the same could be said of Enron, Bernie Madoff and the Nixon White House. That statement doesn't make me feel better.
There were no error or errors committed by VW.   The company intended to cheat and did so successfully.  I hope they go out of business.
I am in the same "boat."  I think this whole diesel thing is a joke.  The diesel signs are in Green when I need to fill up.  It's all marketing and big business manipulation.

I half agree with you. I own a Jetta affected by this scandal, and I do not consider myself indignant. I understand that my car is of course cleaner than the 18-wheeler diesels, but we were made to believe that these would be as clean as the competitors at a cheaper cost. Shame on us for trying to save a buck and not look into the ramifications of that. I feel partially to blame for not researching my car further. How could I know, though? I'm just a small-town, Louisiana bumpkin. I can change a tire, oil, and fill the wiper fluid. Other than that...I trusted VW to provide me with an honest, durable vehicle. I believe that jail time is a little harsh for those involved. That is more of a moral issue than a legal one. I do, however, feel I am owed something since my car is now worth nothing. What will happen if someone smashes into my Jetta? Will I get nothing back for it for being trusting of the people who should have known better?
Wrong.  They are not scared to sacrifice air quality and company integrity for profits.

I find it comical that TDI owners are so indignant about this issue, a complete overreaction. They still have great cars that are FAR cleaner than diesels found in heavy transport. And, as we can see from this article, as time goes on we learn more about what really happened and I'm confident that upper management would never have supported such a fraud, and had no idea what was going on in the trenches.
This matter is an error in corporate organisation leading to a failure to detect regulatory fraud, and it's purely up to VAG and the authorities to sort it out, not the owners who purchased in good faith. Few people would know this, but VW pulled TDI diesels out of the California market, once in the late '90s and again about 2004 because they could not meet their corporate emissions, so they are not scared of sacrificing sales to do things right.
This company lacks  organizational integrity. Period. Someone needs to go to jail. I will never purchase a Volkswagen.
I agree.  However, I do own a VW, a classic Volkswagen Vanagon GL Campmobile (for the uninitiated, a VW camper "Bus").

It took a while, but Volkswagen has announced that they will correct the cheat code.

It guarantees that neither the performance nor the fuel consumption will be negatively affected.

Can somebody -preferably of Volkswagen- please explain how to do this.

One of the most reasonable suggestions that I have read is that Volkswagen should buy the NOx credit on the world market to offset the negative impact of their fraud.

On the other hand, I do not understand why other car manufacturers have not started a class action against Volkswagen. One can imagine that they have lost out on sales by the dishonest claims of Volkswagen to be superior to other car producers.

And what's wrong with locking our doors? Jimmy Carter did it during the Iran crisis. That law is on the books. 8 U.S. Code § 1182 - Inadmissible aliens
It is not Unconstitutional, it is the law of the land. And it was utilized by Jimmy Carter, no less, in 1979 to keep Iranians out of the United States, but he actually did more. He made all Iranian students already here check in, and then he deported a ton of 'em.
In November the 1979 United States attorney general had given all Iranian students one month to report to the local immigration office. Seven thousand were found in violation of their visas, 15,000 Iranians were forced to leave the United States, 1979.
This law was passed in 1952. Do you know what was going on in 1952, among other things? There was no immigration in 1952. It was shut down. Immigration was shut down 1924 to 1965. And why did we have this? What was the need for this in 1952? Oh, yeah, we had rampant illegal immigration. I'm talking about we suspended legal immigration from 1924 to 1965, but we were being overrun in 1952 like we always are. We're the last great hope of the world. That law was written to allow the president to keep undesirables out and to kick undesirables out.

Robert Dear shoots up a clinic to 'save the babies' according to his professed Christian beliefs, and America shrugs and calls it the 'cost of freedom.' An American born citizen with a foreign wife shoots up his workplace with a similar arsenal, according to his own radicalized beliefs supposedly rooted in Islam, and America looses its mind with fear.

In what way is America "the last great hope of the world" when you identify that greatness with the period of McCarthyism and the Red Scare -- rampant paranoia fostering the Cold War as well as Korea and Vietnam? And identify that "greatness" with keeping immigrants 'out?'

Strengthen the screening system by all means. But that is not what Trump is proposing. And while Carter's actions establish a precedent with Iranians -- to classify an entire religion as 'undesirables' goes far beyond that. And while perhaps constitutionally defensible, that does not make it a good, productive, or even rational idea.

How can you classify that entire group of people -- based only on religious belief -- as "undesirables?"

Other civilized countries -- like Canada, for instance -- are demonstrating guts and good will. In what way does our cowering in fear demonstrate our "greatness?"

I had an Iranian roommate in college during those Carter years. He was a good and decent person. His fight against being deported (as an "undesirable") was a fight for his life. If he was sent back to Iran, he faced certain death.

He prevailed and was able to stay, and remains a good and productive person. That was not a time of American "greatness." And he was not an "undesirable."

America is a crowded theater, and Trump is shouting 'Fire' at the top of his lungs.

And he wants to lock the doors until we figure out 'what's going on.'

Temporarily of course.

Why is Malloy being applauded? Isn't this the point of career politicians to do their jobs? Why would you sell a weapon to any person on a "terror list"?? Shouldn't that have been the case from the start? Also, if you are on this secret "terror list" why aren't you already in jail or deported? Or is this "secret list" just a gov't list for anyone who doesn't agree with our President?

Game-Theory Fail.

This is completely the wrong thing to do. If you tell terrorists that trying to buy a gun in Connecticut will draw the attention of authorities than they'll just go somewhere else or attack some other way. Instead, they shouldn't even elude to the fact that anti-terrorism agents are watching the background-check system and then send someone to have a chat with the suspect after his name pops up showing that he's trying to buy guns.

Not that any of this matters. Conn already has very strict laws on what kinds of gun are available. AR-15s are not. Terrorists aren't interested in revolvers and pistols with little 10 shot magazines.

Worse, they'll end up snagging someone who shouldn't even be on any list and prompt them to bring the issue to the Supreme Court... And they will almost surely succeed in getting the whole watch-list program shutdown. It's legality is dubious as it is.

If you want the no-fly list program brought to an end the you should support this move. If you like it and think it helps keep the nation safe then you should oppose this.
Why are these people on the list walking around free? Maybe because they haven't committed a crime? What happened to innocent until proven guilty?
Are you serious? Previously it's not been illegal to sell firearms to people on a terrorist watchlist?

Thank you, Governor, for your leadership. CT is proud of you.

What purpose is the gun-lovers' allegiance to the second amendment if not to protect the American people from their imaginary enemies? And yet they would use the same amendment to consciously endanger the public from those we know are our enemies.

That's bizarre and, well, stupid.
Absolutely brilliant comment.  Thank you!

The Mets were a .500 team before Cespedes showed up.  If they don't resign him or replace him with a similar power-hitting type who reliably drives in runs they will likely revert to mediocrity sooner rather than later, burning out those good young starters in the process.  They can't assume that there will be a Cespedes clone available at the trading deadline next year or that they won't be buried 15 games back of the division-leader if such a player does materialize at that point.
The GOP as you may have known it is defunct,  something new is on the horizon.

"Of course the Donald is a buffoon"

And you think Obama isn't?

As I read these comments- Of course the Donald is a buffoon. He has so many evident character flaws. If you had a guy like that at your poker game, you'd have to change nights or location. Most people, with a tendency to brag about themselves continuously, were broken of the habit by classmates in the 5th or 6th grade.

Apparently his money allowed him to avoid all those situations where he might be forced to grow up. He's gotten to the age of 69 with all that spoiled obnoxious rich kid still in him. Somehow people are flocking to him that 60 years ago would have been running the other way.

I'm not one of them. I'm still interested in what he will do to the Grand Old Party. I think he's a train going way too fast down the track and approaching a curve. It will not be a smooth ending.

First they came for the Socialists, and I did not speak out—
Because I was not a Socialist.

Then they came for the Trade Unionists, and I did not speak out—
Because I was not a Trade Unionist.

Then they came for the Jews, and I did not speak out—
Because I was not a Jew.

Then they came for me—and there was no one left to speak for me.

- Martin Niemoeller, ~1948

Pretty much the same people now endorsing suppression of the rights of those on the watch lists were equally incensed by the notion that the NSA was storing telephone call records in a database. Is the difference simply that they think they are not on a terrorist watch list, but know that they made telephone calls?
Possibly even belonging to the "wrong" political party will get one on the list.

Well said, and what the Gov. is saying is if you are on a terrorist watch list you can't buy a gun, well why are the letting these people stay over here in the first place. Our government has sold this country down the drain.

What puts someone on the Terrorists Watch List/No Fly List?  Is it what you read on the internet, what library book you check out, what newspaper you read,  who your friends are or a secret  telephone call to the FBI from an enemy. No conviction for a crime, just a name on a list is justification to violate an individuals constitutional rights? What other rights are we ready to violate in the name of safety?  The feds know who on the list purchased firearms, would be interested to know if they took any action?

Who really looks at candidate tax plans a year before an election? I think the intended audience is deep pocketed contributors with huge tax bills. If a candidate can cut my taxes by $50,000 per year, it is a good investment to give that candidate $25,000 for his campaign.

It's just business.
Trump is also speaking to Muslims, Latinos, disabled people and women and they don't like a thing they've heard.
